content.question: A particle moves along the x-axis so that at any time t, <math><semantics><mrow><mtext>t</mtext><mo>≥</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow><annotation>MathType@MTEF@5@5@+=feaagCart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLnhiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr4rNCHbGeaGqiVu0Je9sqqrpepC0xbbL8F4rqqrFfpeea0xe9Lq=Jc9vqaqpepm0xbba9pwe9Q8fs0=yqaqpepae9pg0FirpepeKkFr0xfr=xfr=xb9adbaqaaeGaciGaaiaabeqaamaabaabaaGcbaGaaeiDaiabgwMiZkaaicdaaaa@396B@</annotation></semantics></math> , its acceleration is <math><semantics><mrow><mtext>a</mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mtext>t</mtext><mo>)</mo></mrow><mtext> </mtext><mo>=</mo><mtext> </mtext><mo>−</mo><mtext>4 sin</mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mtext>2t</mtext></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><annotation>MathType@MTEF@5@5@@43F3@</annotation></semantics></math> . If the velocity of the particle at <math><semantics><mrow><mtext>t</mtext><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow><annotation>MathType@MTEF@5@5@+=feaagCart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLnhiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr4rNCHbGeaGqiVu0Je9sqqrpepC0xbbL8F4rqqrFfpeea0xe9Lq=Jc9vqaqpepm0xbba9pwe9Q8fs0=yqaqpepae9pg0FirpepeKkFr0xfr=xfr=xb9adbaqaaeGaciGaaiaabeqaamaabaabaaGcbaGaaeiDaiabg2da9iaaicdaaaa@38AB@</annotation></semantics></math> is <math><semantics><mrow><mtext>v</mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mtext>7</mtext></mrow><annotation>MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3AF0@</annotation></semantics></math>  and its position at <math><semantics><mrow><mtext>t</mtext><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow><annotation>MathType@MTEF@5@5@+=feaagCart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLnhiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr4rNCHbGeaGqiVu0Je9sqqrpepC0xbbL8F4rqqrFfpeea0xe9Lq=Jc9vqaqpepm0xbba9pwe9Q8fs0=yqaqpepae9pg0FirpepeKkFr0xfr=xfr=xb9adbaqaaeGaciGaaiaabeqaamaabaabaaGcbaGaaeiDaiabg2da9iaaicdaaaa@38AB@</annotation></semantics></math> is <math><semantics><mrow><mtext>x</mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow><annotation>MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3AF2@</annotation></semantics></math> , then its position at time t is <math><semantics><mrow><mtext>x</mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mtext>t</mtext><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo></mrow><annotation>MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3A75@</annotation></semantics></math>

topic.text: 8.2: Connecting Position, Velocity, and Acceleration Functions Using Integrals

skill.text: Skill 1.D: Identify an appropriate mathematical rule or procedure based on the relationship between concepts (e.g., rate of change and accumulation) or processes (e.g., differentiation and its inverse process, anti-differentiation) to solve problems.
